            m = i;

    }
}

Let me look at the getPoints function in Java:

public static int[] getPoints(int n, int k, int l, int r, int sAll, int sk) {
    int[] ans = new int[n];
    Arrays.fill(ans, l);
    sAll -= sk + (n - k) * l;
    sk -= k * l;
    while (sk > 0) {
        int idx = n - 1;
        while (sk > 0 && idx >= n - k) {
            ans[idx--]++;
            sk--;
        }
    }
    while (sAll > 0) {
        int idx = 0;
        while (sAll > 0 && idx < n - k) {
            ans[idx++]++;
            sAll--;
        }
    }
    return ans;
}

Now, putting it all together.

The C code would be:

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {

    int n, k, l, r, sAll, sk;

    scanf("%d %d %d %d %d %d", &n, &k, &l, &r, &sAll, &sk);

    int ans[n]; // assuming C99 or later for VLA

    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        ans[i] = l;
    }

    // Adjust sAll and sk
    sAll -= sk + (n - k) * l;
    sk -= k * l;

    // Distribute sk to the last k elements
    while (sk > 0) {
        int idx = n - 1;
        while (sk > 0 && idx >= n - k) {
            ans[idx]++;
            sk--;
            idx--;
        }
    }

    // Distribute sAll to the first (n -k) elements
    while (sAll > 0) {
        int idx = 0;
        while (sAll > 0 && idx < n - k) {
            ans[idx]++;
            sAll--;
            idx++;
        }
    }

    // Get the first element of ans
    int x = ans[0];
    int result = (x == 1) ? 0 : 1;

    printf("%d\n", result);

    return 0;
}

Wait, but in the first loop, the code is distributing sk to the last k elements. The loop starts at the end and moves backward until it reaches n -k (the start of the last k elements). Each iteration increases the current element and decreases sk until sk is 0.

The second loop distributes sAll to the first n-k elements, starting from the beginning and moving forward until the first n-k elements are exhausted.

This should replicate the Java code's behavior.
